prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This frequency setting covers 84.4 - 88.1 GHz in LSB and 96.3 - 100.2 GHz in USB. With this setting, OCS(85.139 GHz), c-C3H2 (85.339 GHz), H13CN (86.340 GHz), H13CO+ (86.754 GHz), SiO (86.847 GHz), CCH (87.317 GHz, 87.402 GHz), HNCO (87.925 GHz), CH3OH (96.741 GHz), CS (97.981 GHz), and HC3N (100.076 GHz) can be simaltaneously observed. As for the correlator setting, we choose the band width of 1875 MHz with a frequency resolution of 1.938 MHz which corresponds to a velocity resolution of 6.8 km/s at 85 GHz. This velocity resolution is reasonable to resolve the velocity structure, because a typical line width of NGC 3627 is 60 km/s.

The expected angular resolution of 1.5 arcsec crresponds to the 80 pc at 11 Mpc. The resolution corresponds to a typical size of giant molecular cloud associations. According to CO observation with BIMA (Helfer et al. 2003), largest structure of ythe CO molecule is less than 12 arcsec. Hence, we do not use ACA in this study.

The CCH is detected with 5 mK in the bar-end of NGC 3627 with the IRAM 30 m telescope. If the beam filling factor of 50 is assumed, the expected peak intensity of the CCH line will be 250 mK. After observation time of 1.54 hours, the rms noise level of 30 mK can be acheived with the velocity resolution of 15 km/s. With this sensitivity, we can obtain the CCH maps with a reasonable S/N ratio (> 8). This velocity resolution of 15 km/s used for the sensitivity calculation is sufficient to resoleve velocity structure, because typical line width of NGC 3627 is 60 km/s.

This frequency setting covers 87.82 - 91.4 GHz in LSB. With this setting, HNCO (87.925 GHz), HCN (88.631 GHz), HCO+ (89.189 GHz), and HNC (90.664 GHz) can be simaltaneously observed. As for the correlator setting, we choose the band width of 1875 MHz with a frequency resolution of 1.938 MHz which corresponds to a velocity resolution of 6.4 km/s at 90 GHz. This velocity resolution is reasonable to resolve the velocity structure, because a typical line width of NGC 3627 is 60 km/s.

The expected angular resolution of 1.5 arcsec crresponds to the 80 pc at 11 Mpc. The resolution corresponds to a typical size of giant molecular cloud associations. According to CO observation with BIMA (Helfer et al. 2003), largest structure of the CO molecule is less than 12 arcsec. Hence, we do not use ACA in this study.

The HNC is detected with 7 mK in the bar-end of NGC 3627 with the IRAM 30 m telescope. If the beam filling factor of 50 is assumed, the expected peak intensity of the HNC line will be 350 mK. After observation time of 1.22 hours, the rms noise level of 40 mK can be acheived with the velocity resolution of 15 km/s. With this sensitivity, we can obtain the HNC maps with a reasonable S/N ratio (> 8). This velocity resolution of 15 km/s used for the sensitivity calculation is sufficient to resoleve velocity structure, because typical line width of NGC 3627 is 60 km/s.

This frequency setting covers 93.0 - 96.9 GHz in LSB and 105.1 - 108.8 GHz in USB. With this setting, N2H+(93.173 GHz), C34S (96.413 GHz), CH3OH (96.741 GHz), CCS (106.348 GHz), and 13CN (108.651 GHz) can be simaltaneously observed. As for the correlator setting, we choose the band width of 1875 MHz with a frequency resolution of 1.938 MHz which corresponds to a velocity resolution of 6.2 km/s at 94 GHz. This velocity resolution is reasonable to resolve the velocity structure, because a typical line width of NGC 3627 is 60 km/s.

The expected angular resolution of 1.5 arcsec crresponds to the 80 pc at 11 Mpc. The resolution corresponds to a typical size of giant molecular cloud associations. According to CO observation with BIMA (Helfer et al. 2003), largest structure of the CO molecule is less than 12 arcsec. Hence, we do not use ACA in this study.

The N2H+ is detected with 2 mK in the bar-end of NGC 3627 with the IRAM 30 m telescope. If the beam filling factor of 50 is assumed, the expected peak intensity of the N2H+ line will be 100 mK. After observation time of 2.56 hours, the rms noise level of 25 mK can be acheived with the velocity resolution of 15 km/s. With this sensitivity, we can obtain the N2H+ maps with a reasonable S/N ratio (> 4). This velocity resolution of 15 km/s used for the sensitivity calculation is sufficient to resoleve velocity structure, because typical line width of NGC 3627 is 60 km/s.

This frequency setting covers 97.8 - 101.4 GHz in LSB and 109.7 - 113.6 GHz in USB. With this setting, CS (97.891 GHz), SO (99.300 GHz), HC3N (100.076 GHz), C18O (109.782 GHz), HNCO (109.906 GHz), 13CO (110.201 GHz), C17O (112.359 GHz), and CN (113.191 GHz, 113.491 GHz) can be simaltaneously observed. As for the correlator setting, we choose the band width of 1875 MHz with a frequency resolution of 1.938 MHz which corresponds to a velocity resolution of 5.3 km/s at 110.6 GHz. This velocity resolution is reasonable to resolve the velocity structure, because a typical line width of NGC 3627 is 60 km/s.

The expected angular resolution of 1.5 arcsec crresponds to the 80 pc at 11 Mpc. The resolution corresponds to a typical size of giant molecular cloud associations. According to the CO observation with BIMA (Helfer et al. 2003), largest structure of CO molecule is less than 12 arcsec. Hence, we do not use ACA in this study.

The C18O is detected with 10 mK in the bar-end of NGC 3627 with the IRAM 30 m telescope. If the beam filling factor of 50 is assumed, the expected peak intensity of the C18O line will be 500 mK. After observation time of 1.27 hours, the rms noise level of 25 mK can be acheived with the velocity resolution of 15 km/s. With this sensitivity, we can obtain the C18O maps with a sufficient S/N ratio (> 20). This velocity resolution of 15 km/s used for the sensitivity calculation is sufficient to resoleve velocity structure, because typical line width of NGC 3627 is 60 km/s.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: An astrochemical approach is now becoming a standard method to study environmental conditions not only in Galactic sources but also in external galaxies. A potential application of the astrochemical approach is studies of star-formation feedback to molecular clouds. Since a chemical composition is sensitive to current and past environmental conditions which cannot readily be studied by conventional observations with the CO lines, it can be used to highlight the regions affected by star-formation feedback. In this program, we will test this idea in the barred spiral galaxy NGC3627 with the high spatial resolution (~80 pc) of ALMA. NGC3627 has a vigorous H II regions at the bar end, and is an ideal target to explore the chemical composition influenced by the star-formation feedback. By comparing the chemical compositions of the bar end with those in the spiral arm and the bar, we will be able to establish the star-formation feedback effect on chemical compositions. The result will be a fundamental base for astrochemical diagnostics of external galaxies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2013.1.00889.S, Chemical Variation between a Spiral Arm and a Bar in M83, Yoshimasa Watanabe
